comment.narrative: Organization of the project kick-off meeting. Preparation of terms of reference for the project team.
Project kick-off meeting organized. Terms of references for the project staff prepared and announced.

▪ Following a series of analyses and desk reviews, conducting consultative meetings regarding climate projections updates. Preparing climate vulnerability assessments on the sectoral basis and estimating the financial needs to submit a final report on climate change impact and vulnerability assessments for the priority sectors. ▪ Preparation of 4 urban climate impact and vulnerability assessments. ▪ Conducting a desk review of NASAP prioritization methodologies and a comparative analysis of the Turkish NASAP with selected EU member states. Conducting consultative meetings to discuss the update methodologies for the NASAP. ▪ Starting the work on preparation of UASAPs by conducting a desk review of city-wide adaptation actions based on vulnerability assessments and organizing 4 one-day consultative meetings to discuss the scope of UASAPS. ▪ Conducting a desk review to take stock of existing and expected future climate financing mechanisms at international and national level, to analyze climate financing strategies of selected EU member states with national adaptation strategies, and to evaluate existing finance mechanisms for other themes for best practices and lessons learned. ▪ Conducting a desk review to take stock of existing climate financing mechanisms at city level among EU member states, to analyze climate financing strategies of selected EU member states with UASAPs, and to evaluate existing finance mechanisms in Turkish cities for other themes for best practices and lessons learned. ▪ Organizing consultative meetings to identify strategic points for capacity building. Conducting a survey and preparing a final assessment report on policy and stakeholder capacity & need assessment. ▪ Starting the work on capacity building and networking plan based on the need assessment. Preparing 10 climate change adaptation modules to be used in training sessions and study visits. ▪ Establishment of the National Adaptation Platform and organizing its media launch / technical presentation to the key stakeholders. ▪ Preparing a training module on managing grants for the MOEU/DGEUFR staff and organizing training sessions. (The first training* will be on “Grant Scheme Implementation Process” including guidelines development, launch, evaluation and contracting. The second training will be on “Grant Projects Management and Monitoring” including implementation rules, contract management and monitoring and evaluation.) ▪ Establishment of the CCAGPs MIS system. ▪ Establishment of the CCAGPs M&E system. ▪ Preparation and submission of the Projects Third and Fourth Activity Reports. ▪ Preparation and submission of the Projects Second Progress Report.

The studies in the second year of the project provided a strong basis for the development of policy, technical and operational baselines to establish an enabling environment for climate change adaptation in Turkey.
Under Component 1
• The report on existing climate change adaptation works including the comparative assessment, multi-parameter analysis framework, classification system, compilation of existing work and list of best practices was submitted to and approved by the End Recipient • Sensitivity analysis to understand the performance of the climate models was submitted to and approved by the End Recipient • Climate projections update for sector use using Global Circulation Models outputs with regional models and available Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change scenarios was submitted to and approved by the End Recipient • An indicator-based climate vulnerability assessment scoping including a synopsis of the sectors, key stakeholders, and a methodology for a vulnerability index map in line with IPCC (AR5) was submitted to and approved by the End Recipient • The consultative meetings were held on water resources, agriculture, tourism / cultural heritage social development, health, industry, urban, transportation / communication, energy, ecosystem services (land, coast) sectors. It was organized online with the participation of public institutions, universities, non-governmental organizations and private sector representatives. In the meetings, sectoral vulnerability and risk analysis methodology was consulted within the framework of climate hazards, exposure, sensitivity, adaptation capacity factors. The meeting report summarizing the discussion and incorporating the contributions from the stakeholder representatives was submitted to and approved by the End Recipient • The studies for 10 sector climate vulnerability assessment covering a brief sector overview with trends, volume, affinities, opportunities, threats and uncertainties, the main vulnerability factors to different climatic hazards, existing adaptive capacity, and annualized impact estimation, including any potential domino impact (within the same sector) and cascading impact (to other sectors) have been initiated. • The Climate Change Economy Report was submitted to and approved by the End Recipient . • A desk review of NASAP prioritization methodologies among EU member states, including good practices and lessons learned and a stock-taking exercise on national strategies and policies for priority sectors, and international commitments and developments under multilateral environmental processes, such as the Paris Agreement, Sendai Framework and SDGs was submitted to and approved by the End Recipient • A comparative analysis of the Turkish NASAP with selected EU member states, including the elaboration and update process, organizational and financial aspects, methodologies used for developing the strategy and prioritizing the actions, and recommendations for improvement in the context of Turkey with linkages to the SDGs was submitted to and approved by the End Recipient. Additionally, a two-day consultative meeting on the updating methodology of NASAP was organized where presentations on the examples from EU countries on climate change strategy and action plan preparations, multiple hazard assessments results for Turkey, current national climate change adaptation strategy and action plan (2011-2023) preparation process, methodologies for prioritizing actions, and the EU country examples were made. The discussions were made with the stakeholder representatives from academia, public institutions, private sector, NGOs and local government • A desk review to take stock of existing adaptation indicators and governance mechanisms from EU member states, identify relevant indicators already existing in national and local M&E systems, and identify different M&E governance models (e.g. climate M&E officer, assigned staff under climate change unit) applicable for Turkey and staff time, budget and capacity development required for these models was submitted to and approved by the End Recipient.
Under Component 2
• Adaptation guidelines and urban typology framework for cities was submitted to and approved by the End Recipient • A review and update of climate projections for urban use using Global Circulation Models outputs with regional models and available Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change scenarios was submitted to and approved by the End Recipient • An urban climate vulnerability assessment scoping including a synopsis of the 4 pilot cities with socio-economic, environmental and organizational overview, key stakeholders, and a methodology for an urban vulnerability index map which accounts for the vulnerabilities of regional economic linkages and ecosystems that make up the hinterland of urban areas was submitted to and approved by the End Recipient • The report based on the meetings held on December 2020 to discuss the “Climate Change Impact and Vulnerability Assessment in Four Pilot Cities was submitted and approved” • In addition, 4 two-day hybrid consultative meetings were held on 6-7 July 2021 for Sakarya, 12-13 July 2021 for Konya, 19-20 August 2021 for Samsun and 23-24 July 2021 for Muğla with the participation of the representatives from the stakeholders from the public sector, private sector, civil society, and academia. Following the presentations made by the project experts, the issues on data provision for the vulnerability and risk assessments, and challenges and opportunities faced by the cities in the adaptation processes to climate change were consulted. • The studies for 4 urban climate impact and vulnerability assessment covering a brief sector overview with trends, volume, affinities, opportunities, threats and uncertainties, the main vulnerability factors to different climatic hazards, the existing adaptive capacity, and the annualized impact estimation, including any potential domino impact (within the same sector) and cascading impact (to other sectors) have been initiated. • A desk review of city-wide adaptation actions based on vulnerability assessments through stakeholder engagement at EU level and within EU member states was submitted to and approved by the End Recipient • In order to develop adaptation plans to climate change at the local level, 4 one-day online consultative meetings were held on 7 June 2021 for Sakarya, 8 June 2021 for Konya, 9 June 2021 for Muğla and 10 June 2021 for Samsun with the participation of 262 representatives from the stakeholders from the public sector, private sector, civil society, and academia to discuss the local climate change adaptation strategy and action plans • During the meetings scheduled for a full day, following the presentation of the climate change adaptation strategy and action plan process to the stakeholders, presentations were made by the project experts on the issues of the sectoral impacts of climate change, action plans and adaptation actions. • The studies for 4 UASAPs for the pilot cities including structural and non-structural adaptation measures and using the vulnerability index map developed in Activity 2.2 has been initiated. • A desk review to take stock of existing adaptation indicators and governance mechanisms (e.g. SMART indicators) from EU cities, to identify relevant indicators already existing in national and local M&E systems, and to identify different M&E governance models (e.g. climate M&E officer, assigned staff under climate change unit) applicable for cities in Turkey and staff time, budget and capacity development required for these models was submitted to and approved by End Recipient
Under Component 3
• Consultative meetings were held via online tools for project stakeholders (public institutions, universities, non-governmental organizations and private sector) between 14-16 June 2021 and four pilot cities between 21-22 June 2021 with the participation of 552 representatives in total. Draft meeting report was submitted to End Recipient. • In the meetings, adaptation process was consulted within the framework of capacity building and basic assumptions for inclusive adaptive action, stakeholder needs and options, and general elements and implementation methods of the capacity building plan. • Policy and stakeholder capacity and need assessment was submitted to End Recipient • A capacity building plan was submitted to End Recipient • A desktop review and meetings with related stakeholders to take stock of similar national platforms among EU member states and at EU-level (such as climate-ADAPT), to provide recommendations for the national adaptation platform, to identify knowledge gaps and communication issues among Turkish stakeholders, and to identify international and national networks and online platforms and libraries of relevance and interest was submitted to and approved by End Recipient • Software design and test runs of the platform, including key components such as: FAQ, contact list, publication and activity database, search function, metadata download and report/map making services were completed • Content upload to the platform (publications, reports, media, etc.) and links with relevant networks and online platforms has been initiated. • Preparations for media launch and technical presentation of the platform to key stakeholders; presentation of climate change adaptation work per sector and development of sector specific infographics and presentation material; organization of two public events (i.e. contest, exhibition) on climate change adaptation work have been initiated. • The report based on the first two sessions of Grant Scheme Implementation Process Training held on December 2020 was submitted and approved. • Implementation Guidelines, Visibility Manual, Procurement Guidelines, Monitoring Guidelines together with their annexes were submitted and approved. Turkish translations of guidelines were submitted; first set of comments were received, and revised guidelines were re-submitted. • The report based on the first part of Information Days on concept note application process was held on October and November 2020 was submitted and approved. The draft agenda for second part of Information Days on full application process was submitted; comments were received, revised version was re-submitted.

▪ Project Initiation ▪ Establishment of the Project Team ▪ Organization of the Launch Event & Inception Workshop ▪ Preparation and submission of the Projects Inception report. ▪ Preparation and submission of the Projects First and Second Activity Reports. ▪ Preparation and submission of the Projects First Progress Report. ▪ Identification of the four metropolitan municipalities. ▪ Organization of multiple consultative meetings with relevant stakeholders. ▪ Preparation of the CCAGP Grant guideline. ▪ Organization of multiple info-day sessions / trainings on the CCAGP. ▪ Preparation of reports and desk reviews on existing climate change adaptation works, climate change adaptation grant programmes, M&E systems at the national and local level & national/EU adaptation platform.

▪ Project launch event, inception workshop, ten Operation Coordination Unit meetings and two Project Steering Committee Meetings were held. Additionally an on the Spot Check Monitoring Meeting was organized by the Contracting Authority on 30 June 2020. ▪ Recruitment processes of the Project Team were finalized. ▪ Procurement processes were completed for the key experts on climate impacts and modeling, sectoral adaptation, and urban adaptation (on 3 June 2020, 15 July 2020, and 25 June 2020 respectively). The key expert on software development and database management, who was contracted under POPS project, also became eligible to assist CCA team after an amendment was made to the ICs contract. ▪ The Inception Report and all the annexes with Turkish translation were officially submitted on 12 May 2020 and officially approved on 4 June 2020. ▪ The First Activity Report and all the annexes with Turkish translation were officially submitted on 12 August 2020 and officially approved on 18 September 2020. ▪ English and Turkish Versions of the Second Activity Report were approved and will be officially submitted after the official submission letter is signed. ▪ The First Progress Report was submitted for approval on 07.12.2020. ▪ Four pilot metropolitan municipalities (Konya, Muğla, Sakarya, Samsun) were identified based on a prioritization study in collaboration with the stakeholders. ▪ Consultative meetings on urban adaptation guidelines and city typologies, software development of national adaptation platform and climate change impact assessments were held (via Zoom platform as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic). ▪ Grant guidelines were submitted and approved. Multiple Info-day/training sessions on the CCAGP were held with the relevant stakeholders (via Zoom platform as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic). ▪ Consultative meetings on city level impact and vulnerability assessments with the representative of pilot metropolitan municipalities will be held during the course of December 2020. As of 23 December 2020, the first three of these meetings were completed successfully. ▪ Reports on the assessment of the climate models used by the Turkish State Meteorological Services and DG Water Management , on existing climate change adaptation works / guidelines, on existing climate change adaptation grant programmes, on national adaptation platforms and EU Climate Adaptation Platform (Climate-ADAPT), and on monitoring and evaluation systems at national and local level (for the NASAP and UASAPs) were submitted. ▪ Activities related with the capacity building component have been initiated and two draft working documents for the main report have been submitted. Due to the pandemic, trainings, seminars, events and relevant desk studies have been postponed. ▪ The design process of the National Adaptation Platform including technical background and user interface has been initiated. The initial design will be ready by April 2021.
